SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: SCHEDULE C, PART I-A, POLITICAL CAMPAIGN ACTIVITIES
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT ENGAGE IN DIRECT OR INDIRECT POLITICAL CAMPAIGN ACTIVITIES ON BEHALF OF OR IN OPPOSITION TO CANDIDATES FOR PUBLIC OFFICE. THEREFORE, THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT INCUR ANY EXCISE TAX IMPOSED UNDER SECTION 4955 REPORTABLE ON IRS FORM 4720, RETURN OF CERTAIN EXCISE TAXES UNDER CHAPTERS 41 AND 42 OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: SCHEDULE C, PART II-B, LOBBYING ACTIVITY
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE UNIVERSITY ENGAGED IN LOBBYING ACTIVITIES BUT DID NOT MAKE A SECTION 501(H) LOBBYING EXPENDITURE ELECTION BY FILING FORM 5768. THE UNIVERSITY HAS ENGAGED IN DIRECT INTERACTION WITH LEGISLATORS AND STAFF BY TELEPHONE, EMAIL, DIRECT MAIL AND IN PERSON. LOBBYING DISCLOSURES FOR FORM 990 JULY 1, 2013 THROUGH JUNE 30, 2014: ISSUES LOBBIED AT THE FEDERAL LEVEL INCLUDE: -ISSUES RELATED TO EXPANSION AND SIMPLIFICATION OF THE TUITION TAX CREDITS AND DEDUCTIONS, EXTENSION OF IRA CHARITABLE ROLL-OVER PROVISION AND RELATED CHARITABLE GIVING INCENTIVES -ISSUES REGARDING TAX ADMINISTRATION, EMPLOYEE BENEFITS AND HEALTH CARE REFORM -ISSUES RELATED TO COLLEGE AND UNIVERSITY ENDOWMENTS -BUDGET AND APPROPRIATIONS FOR STUDENT FINANCIAL AID, RESEARCH IN NIH, NSF, DOD, DOE, NASA, EPA, HUD, TRANSPORTATION, INTERIOR, HEALTH PROFESSIONS, HUMANITIES AND ARTS ENDOWMENTS -IMMIGRATION LEGISLATION AND STUDENT VISA ISSUES -STUDENT LENDING ISSUES, SPECIFICALLY HEA REAUTHORIZATION, DIRECT LENDING, PELL GRANT FUNDING, STAFFORD LOANS, COLLEGE COST, ACCOUNTABILITY, DISCLOSURES, STEM EDUCATION, PERKINS LOANS, GRADUATE EDUCATION, INTERNATIONAL EDUCATION, AND VETERANS AND MILITARY EDUCATION ISSUES -LEGISLATION CONCERNING MUSEUMS AND HUMANITIES ISSUES -LEGISLATION RELATING TO RESEARCH AND CLEAN ENERGY ISSUES -LEGISLATION CONCERNING THE DATA ACT, HIGH QUALITY RESEARCH ACT, NASA AUTHORIZATION, REVIEW OF GRANTS ADMINISTRATION REFORM, THE FIRST ACT, THE EINSTEIN ACT, THE SECRET SCIENCE REFORM ACT OF 2014 AND COMPETES ACT REAUTHORIZATION -ISSUES RELATED TO THE PATENT TRANSPARENCY AND IMPROVEMENT ACT OF 2013 ISSUES LOBBIED FOR THE STATE OF MASSACHUSETTS -ISSUES RELATED TO TAX POLICY REGARDING NON-PROFITS -ISSUES RELATED TO PRIVATE HIGHER EDUCATION ENDOWMENT FUNDS -ISSUES RELATED TO MUNICIPAL RELIEF FUNDS -ISSUES RELATED TO REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR NON-PROFITS

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule D, Part III, Line 1a, Collections of art - financial statement footnote
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE UNIVERSITY'S VAST ARRAY OF MUSEUMS AND LIBRARIES HOUSES PRICELESS WORKS OF ART, HISTORICAL TREASURES, LITERARY WORKS, AND ARTIFACTS. THESE COLLECTIONS ARE PROTECTED AND PRESERVED FOR PUBLIC EXHIBITION, EDUCATION, RESEARCH, AND THE FURTHERANCE OF PUBLIC SERVICE. THEY ARE NEITHER DISPOSED OF FOR FINANCIAL GAIN NOR ENCUMBERED IN ANY MANNER. ACCORDINGLY, SUCH COLLECTIONS ARE NOT RECORDED FOR FINANCIAL STATEMENT PURPOSES.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule D, Part III, Line 4, Collections of art - description of collections
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: HARVARD ART MUSEUMS: THE HARVARD ART MUSEUMS ARE THREE MUSEUMS (FOGG MUSEUM, BUSCH-REISINGER MUSEUM, ARTHUR M. SACKLER MUSEUM) AND FOUR RESEARCH CENTERS (STRAUS CENTER FOR CONSERVATION AND TECHNICAL STUDIES, CENTER FOR THE TECHNICAL STUDY OF MODERN ART, HARVARD ART MUSEUM ARCHIVES, ARCHAEOLOGICAL EXPLORATION OF SARDIS, TURKEY). THE HARVARD ART MUSEUMS' COLLECTION CONSISTS OF MORE THAN 250,000 OBJECTS IN ALL MEDIA, RANGING IN DATE FROM ANTIQUITY TO THE PRESENT, AND COMING FROM EUROPE, NORTH AMERICA, NORTH AFRICA, THE MIDDLE EAST, SOUTH ASIA, EAST ASIA, AND SOUTHEAST ASIA. THE HARVARD MUSEUMS' ART COLLECTION IS AN IMPORTANT RESOURCE FOR THE HARVARD UNIVERSITY COMMUNITY, AS WELL AS TO A BROADER AUDIENCE OF STUDENTS, SCHOLARS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THE COLLECTION IS USED TO ADVANCE THE KNOWLEDGE AND APPRECIATION OF ART AND ART MUSEUMS THROUGH PROGRAMS INVOLVING RESEARCH, TEACHING, PROFESSIONAL TRAINING, AND PUBLIC EDUCATION. ARNOLD ARBORETUM: THE ARNOLD ARBORETUM OF HARVARD UNIVERSITY IS THE OLDEST PUBLIC ARBORETUM IN NORTH AMERICA AND ONE OF THE WORLD'S LEADING CENTERS FOR THE STUDY OF PLANTS. ADMINISTERED BY THE OFFICE OF THE PROVOST OF HARVARD UNIVERSITY AND A LINK IN BOSTON'S EMERALD NECKLACE OF PARKS, THE ARNOLD ARBORETUM IS A UNIQUE BLEND OF RESPECTED RESEARCH INSTITUTION AND BELOVED PUBLIC LANDSCAPE. WE PROVIDE AND SUPPORT WORLD-CLASS RESEARCH, HORTICULTURE, AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS THAT FOSTER THE UNDERSTANDING, APPRECIATION, AND PRESERVATION OF TREES. COLLECTION OF HISTORICAL SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTS: HARVARD UNIVERSITY HAS BEEN ACQUIRING SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTS ON A CONTINUOUS BASIS FOR TEACHING AND RESEARCH SINCE 1672. THE COLLECTION OF HISTORICAL SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTS, WHICH WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1948 TO PRESERVE THIS APPARATUS AS A RESOURCE FOR TEACHING AND RESEARCH IN THE HISTORY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY, HAS BECOME ONE OF THE THREE LARGEST UNIVERSITY COLLECTIONS OF ITS KIND IN THE WORLD. THE COLLECTION CONTAINS OVER 20,000 OBJECTS DATING FROM ABOUT 1400 TO THE PRESENT. A BROAD RANGE OF SCIENTIFIC DISCIPLINES ARE REPRESENTED, INCLUDING ASTRONOMY, NAVIGATION, HOROLOGY, SURVEYING, GEOLOGY, CALCULATING, PHYSICS, BIOLOGY, MEDICINE, PSYCHOLOGY, ELECTRICITY, AND COMMUNICATION. SIGNIFICANT INSTRUMENTS, MADE OBSOLETE BY NEW TECHNOLOGIES, CONTINUE TO BE INCORPORATED. MANY OF THE DOCUMENTS DETAILING THE PURCHASE AND USE OF THE INSTRUMENTS HAVE BEEN PRESERVED, AND ARE AVAILABLE FOR RESEARCH IN THE COLLECTION'S ADJUNCT LIBRARY. MUSEUM OF COMPARATIVE ZOOLOGY (WITHIN THE MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY): THE MUSEUM OF COMPARATIVE ZOOLOGY (THE MCZ) WAS FOUNDED IN 1859 ON THE CONCEPT THAT COLLECTIONS ARE AN INTEGRAL AND FUNDAMENTAL COMPONENT OF ZOOLOGICAL RESEARCH AND TEACHING. THIS 150-YEAR-OLD COMMITMENT REMAINS A STRONG AND PROUD TRADITION FOR THE MCZ. THE PRESENT-DAY MCZ CONTAINS OVER 21-MILLION SPECIMENS IN TEN RESEARCH COLLECTIONS WHICH COMPRISE ONE OF THE WORLD'S RICHEST AND MOST VARIED RESOURCES FOR STUDYING THE DIVERSITY OF LIFE. THE MUSEUM SERVES AS THE PRIMARY REPOSITORY FOR ZOOLOGICAL SPECIMENS COLLECTED BY PAST AND PRESENT HARVARD FACULTY-CURATORS, STAFF AND ASSOCIATES CONDUCTING RESEARCH AROUND THE WORLD. AS A PREMIER UNIVERSITY MUSEUM AND RESEARCH INSTITUTION, THE SPECIMENS AND THEIR RELATED DATA ARE AVAILABLE TO RESEARCHERS OF THE SCIENTIFIC AND MUSEUM COMMUNITY. USE OF THE COLLECTIONS IN STUDENT RESEARCH, WHETHER AS THESIS WORK OR INDEPENDENT STUDY, IS ALSO ENCOURAGED. FISHER MUSEUM HARVARD FOREST: THE FISHER MUSEUM'S MAIN EXHIBIT DISPLAYS TWENTY-THREE INTERNATIONALLY ACCLAIMED MODELS (DIORAMAS) PORTRAYING THE HISTORY, CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF CENTRAL NEW ENGLAND FORESTS. OTHER EXHIBITS AT THE MUSEUM REPRESENT THE RANGE OF HARVARD FOREST'S RESEARCH. HARVARD UNIVERSITY HERBARIA (WITHIN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY): THE HARVARD UNIVERSITY HERBARIA ARE AMONG SOME SEVERAL THOUSAND COLLECTIONS OF PRESSED, DRIED PLANT SPECIMENS WORLDWIDE THAT ARE USED BY RESEARCHERS TO FURTHER OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE PLANT WORLD. SOME OF THE EARLIEST HERBARIA WERE FOUNDED IN EUROPE IN THE EARLY 1600'S, DURING THE DAYS OF EXPLORATION, WHEN KNOWLEDGE OF THE EARTH'S FLORA WAS GROWING AT SUCH A RAPID PACE THAT BOTANICAL GARDENS COULD NO LONGER MAINTAIN LIVING EXAMPLES OF EVERY KNOWN SPECIES. WHILE HERBARIUM COLLECTIONS OF ALL SIZES EXIST TODAY, THERE ARE FEWER THAN 75 HERBARIA WORLDWIDE WITH MORE THAN ONE MILLION SPECIMENS. HERBARIUM COLLECTIONS HAVE BEEN BUILT UP OVER THE YEARS BY THE EFFORTS OF NUMEROUS BOTANISTS AND PLANT COLLECTORS WHO HAVE SEARCHED FROM REMOTE AND ISOLATED JUNGLES TO INNER CITY WASTE LOTS AND RAILROAD TRACKS TO DOCUMENT THE DIVERSITY AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE EARTH'S FLORA. REPRESENTATIVES OF MOST KNOWN SPECIES OF PLANTS CAN BE FOUND IN HERBARIA TODAY, CAREFULLY MOUNTED ON SHEETS OF ARCHIVAL QUALITY PAPER, LABELED WITH IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THEM, AND STORED ON SHELVES IN CABINETS. IN ESSENCE, A HERBARIUM IS ANALOGOUS TO A LIBRARY OF CAREFULLY PRESERVED PLANTS WHERE THE SPECIMENS THEMSELVES AND THE LABELS ASSOCIATED WITH THEM PROVIDE A WEALTH OF INFORMATION ONCE THEY HAVE BEEN "READ" AND STUDIED BY SCIENTISTS. THE SPECIMENS ARE THE KEY TO UNDERSTANDING PLANT RELATIONSHIPS,GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTIONS, ECONOMIC USEFULNESS, EVEN THEIR MOLECULAR MAKEUP. AS WE LOSE NATURAL HABITATS THE WORLD OVER, HERBARIA INCREASINGLY SERVE AS A RECORD OF THE RECENT HISTORY OF PLANT LIFE, AND AS A REPOSITORY OF PRECIOUS GENETIC INFORMATION. HERBARIA HOLD THE TOOLS FOR OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE PLANT WORLD. MINERALOGICAL AND GEOLOGICAL MUSEUM (WITHIN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY): THE HARVARD MINERAL COLLECTION RANKS AMONG THE WORLD'S FINEST DUE TO ITS VERY BROAD REPRESENTATION, WEALTH OF RARE SPECIES, LARGE NUMBER OF SPECIMENS DESCRIBED IN THE SCIENTIFIC LITERATURE, AND THE QUALITY OF ITS DISPLAY SPECIMENS. A RICH SYSTEMATIC MINERAL COLLECTION AND DISPLAYS OF GEMSTONES ARE THE PRINCIPAL EXHIBITS IN THE MINERAL GALLERY. THE MUSEUM IS COMMITTED TO THE DEVELOPMENT AND PRESERVATION OF WORLD-CLASS COLLECTIONS OF MINERALS, GEMS, ROCKS, ORES, AND METEORITES FOR RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND PUBLIC DISPLAY. ITS EARLIEST COLLECTIONS DATE BACK TO THE LATE 18TH CENTURY. THE MUSEUM CATERS TO THE NEEDS OF STUDENTS AND FACULTY AT HARVARD UNIVERSITY AS WELL AS THE GEOLOGICAL COMMUNITY AT LARGE BY SERVING AS A UNIQUELY RICH RESOURCE OF MATERIALS AND INFORMATION. PEABODY MUSEUM OF ARCHAEOLOGY AND ETHNOLOGY: THE PEABODY MUSEUM OF ARCHAEOLOGY AND ETHNOLOGY IS STEWARD TO ONE OF THE OLDEST AND LARGEST COLLECTIONS OF CULTURAL OBJECTS IN THE WESTERN HEMISPHERE. SINCE THE LATE NINETEENTH CENTURY, THE MUSEUM HAS PLAYED AN ACTIVE PART IN THE HISTORY OF AMERICAN ANTHROPOLOGY AND IN THE EVOLVING RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN MUSEUMS AND NATIVE PEOPLES. AS A UNIVERSITY MUSEUM SITUATED IN AN ACADEMIC AND REGIONAL COMMUNITY CENTRAL TO THE DEVELOPMENT AND THE STUDY OF AMERICAN CIVIC CULTURE, THE PEABODY STRIVES TO MAKE COLLECTIONS WIDELY ACCESSIBLE AND ENGAGE ISSUES OF CONCERN TO DIVERSE AUDIENCES. TODAY, THE PEABODY HOUSES MORE THAN SIX MILLION INDIVIDUAL OBJECTS, 500,000 PHOTOGRAPHIC IMAGES, AND SUBSTANTIAL ARCHIVAL RECORDS. STRONGEST IN THE CULTURES OF NORTH, CENTRAL, AND SOUTH AMERICA, AND THE PACIFIC ISLANDS, THE PEABODY IS ALSO CARETAKER TO IMPORTANT COLLECTIONS FROM AFRICA, EUROPE, AND ASIA. COLLECTION TYPES INCLUDE ARCHAEOLOGY; ETHNOGRAPHY; OSTEOLOGY; AND PAINTING, DRAWING, AND PRINTS. SEMITIC MUSEUM: THE SEMITIC MUSEUM IS HOME TO THE UNIVERSITY'S COLLECTIONS OF NEAR EASTERN ARCHAEOLOGICAL ARTIFACTS. THESE ARTIFACTS COMPRISE OVER 40,000 ITEMS, INCLUDING POTTERY, CYLINDER SEALS, SCULPTURE, COINS AND CUNEIFORM TABLETS. MANY ARE FROM MUSEUM-SPONSORED EXCAVATIONS IN ISRAEL, JORDAN, IRAQ, EGYPT, CYPRUS, AND TUNISIA. THE MUSEUM IS DEDICATED TO THE USE OF THESE COLLECTIONS FOR THE TEACHING, RESEARCH, AND PUBLICATION OF NEAR EASTERN ARCHAEOLOGY, HISTORY, AND CULTURE. WARREN ANATOMICAL MUSEUM: THE WARREN ANATOMICAL MUSEUM'S PRESENT COLLECTION CONTAINS APPROXIMATELY 15,000 ARTIFACTS AND CASES INCLUDING: ANATOMICAL AND PATHOLOGICAL PREPARATIONS; VARIOUS WAX, PAPER MACHE, AND DRY PREPARATION ANATOMICAL MODELS; PHOTOGRAPHS, PRINTS, PAINTINGS, AND DRAWINGS; MEDICAL INSTRUMENTS AND MACHINES; AND OTHER MEDICAL MEMORABILIA. ALONG WITH THE WELL-KNOWN SKULL OF PHINEAS GAGE, THE MUSEUM HOLDS MANY OTHER RARE AND INTERESTING ITEMS. AMONG THESE ARE THE PHRENOLOGICAL COLLECTION OF JOHANN GASPAR SPURZHEIM, THE BOSTON SOCIETY FOR MEDICAL IMPROVEMENT COLLECTION, AND A W. T. G. MORTON-TYPE ETHER INHALER. THE MUSEUM PROMOTES THE COLLECTION FOR THE PURPOSES OF MEDICAL EDUCATION IN ALL FORMS WHENEVER POSSIBLE, BY EXPANDING ITS SCOPE TO PROVIDE PUBLIC PROGRAMMING AND EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES TO THE LARGER COMMUNITY.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule D, Part IV, Line 1b, Agent, trustee, custodian, or other intermediary arrangement
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: AGENCY FUNDS REPRESENT AWARDS UNDER WHICH HARVARD SERVES AS AN INTERMEDIARY AGENT BETWEEN THE SPONSOR (USUALLY FEDERAL) AND THE ULTIMATE THIRD PARTY RECIPIENT. THE TRANSFER OF THE ASSETS TO HARVARD IS NOT A CONTRIBUTION RECEIVED BY HARVARD AND THE TRANSFER OF ASSETS TO THE RECIPIENT IS NOT A CONTRIBUTION MADE BY HARVARD. HARVARD DRAWS DOWN ON ITS FEDERAL LINES OF CREDIT MONTHLY TO COVER THOSE COSTS INCURRED ON FEDERAL AWARDS. THEREFORE, THERE IS NO BEGINNING OR ENDING BALANCE FOR THESE AGENCY FUNDS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule D, Part V, Line 4, Intended uses of endowment funds
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THE ENDOWMENT IS TO SUPPORT THE UNIVERSITY'S TEACHING AND RESEARCH MISSION. THE ENDOWMENT ROLLFORWARDS ON SCHEDULE D, PART V HAVE BEEN RESTATED FOR THE FISCAL YEARS ENDED JUNE 30, 2010 AND 2011 TO PROPERLY EXCLUDE THE ENDOWMENTS OF CERTAIN RELATED ORGANIZATIONS THAT WERE PREVIOUSLY INCLUDED IN THE REPORTED TOTAL. THIS RESTATEMENT DOES NOT CHANGE NET ASSETS REPORTED ON THE FORM 990 BALANCE SHEET FOR THE FISCAL YEARS ENDED JUNE 30, 2010 AND 2011.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: SCHEDULE D, PART X, LINE 2, FIN 48 (ASC 740):
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2007, THE UNIVERSITY ADOPTED FASB INTERPRETATION NO. 48, ACCOUNTING FOR UNCERTAINTY IN INCOME TAXES (FIN 48 (ASC 740)). FIN 48 (ASC 740) SETS A MINIMUM THRESHOLD FOR FINANCIAL STATEMENT RECOGNITION OF THE BENEFIT OF A TAX POSITION TAKEN OR EXPECTED TO BE TAKEN IN A TAX RETURN. TAX POSITIONS FOR THE OPEN TAX YEARS AS OF JUNE 30, 2014 WERE REVIEWED AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT NO PROVISION FOR UNCERTAIN TAX PROVISIONS WAS REQUIRED. ACCORDINGLY, THERE IS NO DISCLOSURE IN THE JUNE 30, 2014 FINANCIAL STATEMENTS REGARDING UNCERTAIN TAX POSITIONS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule E, Part I, Line 3, Racially nondiscriminatory policy
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE ORGANIZATION MEETS THE CRITERIA ESTABLISHED IN SECTION 4.0 REVENUE PROCEDURE 75-50. THE UNIVERSITY DRAWS A SUBSTANTIAL PERCENTAGE OF ITS STUDENTS NATIONWIDE AND WORLDWIDE AND FOLLOWS A RACIALLY NONDISCRIMINATORY POLICY AS TO STUDENTS. IT SATISFIES THE PUBLICITY REQUIREMENT BY INCLUDING A STATEMENT OF ITS RACIALLY NONDISCRIMINATORY POLICY AS TO STUDENTS IN ALL ITS BROCHURES AND CATALOGS DEALING WITH STUDENT ADMISSIONS, PROGRAMS, AND SCHOLARSHIPS. IT ALSO REFERENCES ITS RACIALLY NONDISCRIMINATORY POLICY IN OTHER WRITTEN ADVERTISING THAT IT USES AS A MEANS OF INFORMING PROSPECTIVE STUDENTS OF ITS PROGRAMS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule E, Part I, Line 6a, Financial aid or assistance from a governmental agency
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THIS ORGANIZATION RECEIVES FUNDS FOR RESEARCH AND ADMINISTERS FEDERAL AID PROGRAMS TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN POST-SECONDARY EDUCATION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule F, Part I, Line 2, Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: ALL DISBURSEMENTS MADE BY THIS INSTITUTION IN FURTHERANCE OF ITS EXEMPT PROGRAMS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY DULY AUTHORIZED COMMITTEES OR INDIVIDUALS. ALL SCHOLARSHIPS AND STUDENT LOANS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY HARVARD'S FINANCIAL AID OFFICES. IN ADDITION, HARVARD UNIVERSITY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE PROGRAMMATIC AND FINANCIAL MONITORING OF ITS SPONSORED RESEARCH AWARD SUBRECIPIENTS. PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS AND PROJECT STAFF PERFORM ONGOING REVIEWS OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES. IN ADDITION, ON AN ANNUAL BASIS, UNIVERSITY RESEARCH ADMINISTRATORS REVIEW ALL ACTIVE SUBCONTRACTS AND INQUIRE FURTHER INTO THOSE THAT ARE DEEMED TO REQUIRE CLOSER SCRUTINY IN LIGHT OF A VARIETY OF ATTRIBUTES. UPON IDENTIFICATION OF SUBRECIPIENTS THAT MANDATE CLOSER SCRUTINY, HARVARD IMPLEMENTS ADDITIONAL MONITORING ACTIONS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH SUBAGREEMENT PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS, AND WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS.

UPON IDENTIFICATION OF SUBRECIPIENTS THAT MANDATE CLOSER SCRUTINY, HARVARD IMPLEMENTS ADDITIONAL MONITORING ACTIONS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH SUBAGREEMENT PERFORMANCE, FINANCIAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS, AND WITH ALL APPLICABLE FEDERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a, First-class or charter travel
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: UNIVERSITY TRAVEL POLICY PROHIBITS FIRST CLASS TRAVEL EXCEPT IN LIMITED CIRCUMSTANCES. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THIS POLICY, A SMALL NUMBER OF OFFICERS, KEY EMPLOYEES, AND HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES ARE PERMITTED TO TRAVEL FIRST CLASS ON A SMALL NUMBER OF TRIPS EACH YEAR. TRAVEL EXPENSES ARE INCURRED FOR UNIVERSITY BUSINESS PURPOSES AND ARE THEREFORE NOT TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a, Travel for companions
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: UNIVERSITY TRAVEL POLICY ALLOWS FOR REIMBURSEMENT OF TRAVEL EXPENSES INCURRED BY COMPANION TRAVELERS WHEN THE COMPANION HAS A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN THE BUSINESS PROCEEDINGS, OR MAKES AN IMPORTANT CONTRIBUTION TO THE SUCCESS OF AN EVENT. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THIS POLICY, THE UNIVERSITY REIMBURSED A SMALL NUMBER OF OFFICERS, KEY EMPLOYEES, AND HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES FOR COMPANION TRAVEL DURING THE YEAR. IN THESE LIMITED CIRCUMSTANCES, THE REIMBURSEMENT OF COMPANION AND FAMILY MEMBER TRAVEL EXPENSES WAS A LEGITIMATE BUSINESS EXPENSE FOR THE UNIVERSITY AND THEREFORE IT WAS NOT REPORTED IN THE EMPLOYEES' TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a, Tax indemnification and gross-up payments
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE UNIVERSITY ELECTED TO PAY THE TAX OBLIGATIONS THAT AROSE FROM CERTAIN COMPENSATION TRANSACTIONS AND REIMBURSEMENTS. TWO HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES RECEIVED THIS BENEFIT DURING THE CALENDAR YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2013. THIS TAX REIMBURSEMENT IS REPORTED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a, Housing allowance or residence for personal use
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES PRESIDENT FAUST WITH A RESIDENCE IN CAMBRIDGE AND REQUIRES ITS USE AS CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE TOTAL ESTIMATED VALUE OF THE ANNUAL USE OF THE RESIDENCE IS $180,000, OF WHICH $122,259 IS ESTIMATED TO BE THE VALUE OF THE PERSONAL USE AND IS REPORTED AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT IN PART VII, LINE 1A AND SCHEDULE J, PART II. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES PROVOST GARBER WITH A RESIDENCE IN CAMBRIDGE AND REQUIRES ITS USE AS CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE TOTAL ESTIMATED VALUE OF THE ANNUAL USE OF THE RESIDENCE IS $174,000 OF WHICH $149,101 IS ESTIMATED TO BE THE VALUE OF THE PERSONAL USE AND IS REPORTED AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT IN PART VII, LINE 1A AND SCHEDULE J, PART II. HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL (HBS) PROVIDES DEAN NOHRIA WITH A RESIDENCE IN ALLSTON AND REQUIRES ITS USE AS CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF HBS. THE TOTAL ESTIMATED VALUE OF THE ANNUAL USE OF THE RESIDENCE IS $132,000 OF WHICH $90,472 IS ESTIMATED TO BE THE VALUE OF THE PERSONAL USE AND IS REPORTED AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT IN PART VII, LINE 1A AND SCHEDULE J, PART II. THE FACULTY OF ARTS AND SCIENCES (FAS) PROVIDES DEAN SMITH WITH A RESIDENCE IN CAMBRIDGE AND REQUIRES ITS USE AS CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF FAS. THE DEAN MOVED INTO THE RESIDENCE IN JUNE, 2013. THE TOTAL ESTIMATED VALUE OF THE USE OF THE RESIDENCE FROM JULY 1, 2013 THROUGH DECEMBER 31, 2013 IS $60,000, OF WHICH $39,623 IS ESTIMATED TO BE THE VALUE OF THE PERSONAL USE AND IS REPORTED AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT IN PART VII, LINE 1A AND SCHEDULE J, PART II. DEAN SMITH'S COLUMN B(III) OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION INCLUDES $41,200 OF TAXABLE TRANSITIONAL PAYMENTS TO COVER HIS HOUSING EXPENSES WHILE HIS UNIVERSITY HOUSING WAS BEING RENOVATED. ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE RECEIVED A MORTGAGE SUBSIDY AND/OR HOUSING ALLOWANCE. THIS AMOUNT IS INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEE'S TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a, Health or social club dues or initiation fees
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE UNIVERSITY PAID HARVARD CLUB DUES FOR TAMARA ROGERS, VICE PRESIDENT OF ALUMNI AFFAIRS AND DEVELOPMENT. THIS IS A NONTAXABLE BUSINESS EXPENSE IN FURTHERANCE OF ALUMNI RELATIONS AND DEVELOPMENT.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a, Personal services
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: DURING THE PERFORMANCE OF REGULAR UNIVERSITY DUTIES, A UNIVERSITY EMPLOYEE MAY, ON OCCASION, PERFORM INCIDENTAL PERSONAL SERVICES FOR THE PRESIDENT (E.G., PURCHASING OF SMALL HOUSEHOLD ITEMS, WITH THE COST OF SUCH ITEMS REIMBURSED IN FULL BY THE PRESIDENT). THE UNIVERSITY REGARDS SUCH SERVICES AS A NONTAXABLE "DE MINIMIS" FRINGE BENEFIT.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 1B, COMPENSATION POLICIES:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS WRITTEN POLICIES REGARDING FIRST CLASS TRAVEL AND TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO FOLLOWS WRITTEN GUIDELINES ON HOUSING ALLOWANCES, WHICH ARE OFFERED ON A LIMITED BASIS TO SENIOR FACULTY AND SENIOR ADMINISTRATORS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 3, COMPENSATION REVIEW PROCESS:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: SEE SCHEDULE O "COMPENSATION REVIEW PROCESS" FOR A DISCUSSION OF THE METHODS USED TO ESTABLISH THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 4a, Severance or change-of-control payment
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2013, DR. CHIN, A HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE, ENTERED INTO A SEPARATION AGREEMENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY IN WHICH THE UNIVERSITY AGREED TO PAY HIM A LUMP SUM EQUAL TO 12 MONTHS OF SALARY, OR $468,180. THIS AMOUNT HAS BEEN REPORTED IN COLUMN (B)(III) OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 4b, Supplemental nonqualified retirement plan
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2013, THE UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTED $150,000 TO PRESIDENT FAUST'S DEFERRED COMPENSATION ACCOUNT. THE $150,000 IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (C), "RETIREMENT AND OTHER DEFERRED COMPENSATION". IF THE PRESIDENT REMAINS EMPLOYED AT THE UNIVERSITY, THE AMOUNT WILL FULLY VEST AND BE REPORTED AS TAXABLE INCOME TO THE PRESIDENT IN CALENDAR YEAR 2015.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule M, Part I, Line 33, Explanation of revenues not reported
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: SFAS 116 PROVIDES THAT CONTRIBUTIONS OF WORKS OF ART, HISTORICAL TREASURES, AND SIMILAR ASSETS NEED NOT BE RECOGNIZED AS REVENUES AND CAPITALIZED IF THE DONATED ITEMS ARE ADDED TO COLLECTIONS THAT ARE HELD FOR PUBLIC EXHIBITION, EDUCATION, OR RESEARCH IN FURTHERANCE OF PUBLIC SERVICE RATHER THAN FINANCIAL GAIN. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT REPORT REVENUES FOR GIFTS-IN-KIND INTENDED FOR DISPLAY OR IMMATERIAL AMOUNTS. THE FOLLOWING IS THE TEXT OF THE FOOTNOTE DESCRIBING COLLECTIONS FROM THE UNIVERSITY'S FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: "THE UNIVERSITY'S VAST ARRAY OF MUSEUMS AND LIBRARIES HOUSES PRICELESS WORKS OF ART, HISTORICAL TREASURES, LITERARY WORKS, AND ARTIFACTS. THESE COLLECTIONS ARE PROTECTED AND PRESERVED FOR PUBLIC EXHIBITION, EDUCATION, RESEARCH, AND THE FURTHERANCE OF PUBLIC SERVICES. THEY ARE NEITHER DISPOSED OF FOR FINANCIAL GAIN NOR ENCUMBERED IN ANY MANNER. ACCORDINGLY, SUCH COLLECTIONS ARE NOT RECORDED FOR FINANCIAL STATEMENT PURPOSES." NOT ALL GIFTS ARE ART GIVEN WITH THE INTENTION OF BEING DISPLAYED. THERE MAY BE INSTANCES WHERE A GIFT OF ART IS MADE WITH THE PURPOSE OF BEING SOLD AND THE PROCEEDS BENEFITING A SPECIFIC PURPOSE OR UNIT AT THE UNIVERSITY. IN SUCH CASES, THE SALE PROCEEDS WOULD BE RECORDED AS GIFT REVENUE AT THE TIME OF SALE.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: SCHEDULE M, PART I, LINE 33, OTHER NONCASH CONTRIBUTIONS:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CERTAIN NONCASH CONTRIBUTIONS LISTED IN PART I HAVE NOT REPORTED AN AMOUNT IN PART I, COLUMN (C). NO AMOUNT IS REPORTED FOR THESE CONTRIBUTIONS EITHER BECAUSE THEY ARE INTENDED FOR DISPLAY, AS DISCUSSED ABOVE, OR BECAUSE THE VALUE OF THE NONCASH CONTRIBUTION IS IMMATERIAL.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule M, part I, column (b), Line 1, Number of contributions or items contributed.
FORM 990, PART I, LINE 5, TOTAL NUMBER OF INDIVIDUALS EMPLOYED:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: AS REQUIRED BY THE FORM 990 INSTRUCTIONS, THE NUMBER REPORTED ON PART I, LINE 5 REPRESENTS THE TOTAL NUMBER OF FORMS W-2 PRODUCED BY THE UNIVERSITY DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2013. THIS INCLUDES PAYMENTS FOR WORK STUDY AND CERTAIN TEACHING FELLOWS, AS WELL AS SHORT-TERM EMPLOYMENT. THE TOTAL HEAD COUNT FOR FACULTY AND STAFF AS REPORTED ON THE HARVARD UNIVERSITY FACT BOOK FOR OCTOBER 31, 2013 WAS 17,523.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART I, LINE 6, VOLUNTEERS:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: HARVARD IS FORTUNATE TO BENEFIT FROM THE SERVICES OF VOLUNTEERS ACROSS ITS NUMEROUS SCHOOLS, DEPARTMENTS, AND PROGRAMS. WHILE HARVARD DOES NOT TRACK OR ELSEWHERE REPORT THE NUMBER OF ITS VOLUNTEERS, THE UNIVERSITY ESTIMATES THAT THIS FIGURE EXCEEDS 23,000.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Sec A, Line 7b, Decisions requiring approval by members or stockholders
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CERTAIN ACTIONS OF THE HARVARD CORPORATION, SUCH AS THE ELECTION OF NEW CORPORATION MEMBERS, THE CONFERRAL OF DEGREES, AND AMENDMENTS TO THE UNIVERSITY STATUTES, ARE SUBJECT TO THE CONSENT OF THE UNIVERSITY'S BOARD OF OVERSEERS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Sec B, Line 11b, Review of form 990 by governing body
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE FORM 990 WAS REVIEWED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S TAX RETURN REVIEW COMMITTEES, COMPRISING SENIOR FINANCE STAFF, AND INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL COUNSEL. FORM 990 WAS ALSO REVIEWED BY THE UNIVERSITY'S JOINT COMMITTEE ON INSPECTION, CONSISTING OF MEMBERS OF THE HARVARD CORPORATION AND THE BOARD OF OVERSEERS. THE FINAL FORM 990 WAS PROVIDED TO THE ENTIRE HARVARD CORPORATION BEFORE IT WAS FILED.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Sec B, Line 12c, Conflict of interest policy
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: ANNUALLY, THE UNIVERSITY'S OFFICE OF THE GENERAL COUNSEL DISTRIBUTES A COPY OF THE HARVARD UNIVERSITY POLICY ON CONFLICTS OF INTEREST AND COMMITMENT FOR SENIOR OFFICERS AND SENIOR ADMINISTRATORS, AND AN ANNUAL DISCLOSURE FORM, TO THE INDIVIDUALS SUBJECT TO THE POLICY. THE COMPLETED FORMS ARE REVIEWED BY THE OFFICE OF THE GENERAL COUNSEL. A PARALLEL PROCESS IS CARRIED OUT ANNUALLY BY THE OFFICE OF THE GOVERNING BOARDS FOR THE UNIVERSITY'S GOVERNING BODY. THE COMPLETED DISCLOSURE FORMS OF MEMBERS OF THE GOVERNING BODY ARE REVIEWED BY BOTH THE OFFICE OF THE GENERAL COUNSEL AND THE SECRETARY OF THE UNIVERSITY.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, LINE 15, AND SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 3: COMPENSATION REVIEW PROCESS
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE FOLLOWING IS A DESCRIPTION OF THE ANNUAL COMPENSATION REVIEW PROCESS. THE MOST RECENT REVIEW CONDUCTED PRIOR TO THE CLOSE OF THE FISCAL YEAR 2014 OCCURRED IN MAY 2014. THE OFFICE OF HUMAN RESOURCES INITIATES AN ANNUAL REVIEW PROCESS TIMED SO THAT A FINAL REVIEW CAN BE CONDUCTED BY THE HARVARD CORPORATION DURING ITS APRIL/MAY MEETING. ALL INTERNAL REVIEWS AND NEW SALARY RECOMMENDATIONS ARE CONDUCTED IN ADVANCE OF THE CORPORATION MEETING, GENERALLY INCLUDING RECOMMENDATION BY THE PRESIDENT OF COMPENSATION OTHER THAN THE PRESIDENT'S OWN. THE PROVOST AND THE EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT ADDITIONALLY PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS ON THOSE INDIVIDUALS FOR WHOM THEY HAVE ORGANIZATIONAL RESPONSIBILITY, SUBJECT TO THE APPROVAL OF THE PRESIDENT. DURING THE MEETING, THE CORPORATION, WHICH IN FULL SERVES AS THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE, REVIEWS EACH OF THE PRESIDENT'S PROPOSALS FOR FINAL APPROVAL. THE PRESIDENT DOES NOT PARTICIPATE IN THE DELIBERATIONS OR THE VOTE ON THE PRESIDENT'S OWN COMPENSATION. ALL VOTES ARE MEMORIALIZED IN MINUTES AND PRESERVED, TOGETHER WITH ALL BACKGROUND DATA AND MATERIALS PROVIDED BY THE OFFICE OF HUMAN RESOURCES. THIS ANNUAL REVIEW PROCESS INCLUDES THE COMPILATION OF APPROPRIATE COMPARABILITY COMPENSATION DATA FOR EACH POSITION INCLUDED IN THE REVIEW. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OBTAIN AND RELIED UPON APPROPRIATE COMPENSATION MARKET SURVEY DATA AND ANALYSIS IN EACH CASE PRIOR TO MAKING ITS DETERMINATION. FOR THIS PURPOSE, THE PRINCIPAL SOURCE OF SUCH DATA IS AN ANNUAL REPORT PROVIDED BY AN OUTSIDE CONSULTANT. ADDITIONAL COMPARABILITY DATA FOR REVIEW OF THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION HAS BEEN DRAWN FROM A SECOND EXTERNAL SOURCE THAT IS COMPILED ANNUALLY AND FROM PUBLICLY AVAILABLE FORM 990 INFORMATION. THE INDIVIDUALS TO WHOM THE PROCESS IS APPLIED ARE THE FOLLOWING: 1. THE OFFICERS OF THE UNIVERSITY, INCLUDING THE PRESIDENT, PROVOST, SECRETARY, EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, AND ALL VICE PRESIDENTS; 2. THE DEANS OF THE FACULTIES; 3. CERTAIN OTHER SENIOR UNIVERSITY PERSONNEL

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Sec B, Line 15a, Process to establish compensation of top management official
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: SEE ABOVE (FORM 990, PART VI, LINE 15 AND AND SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 3: COMPENSATION REVIEW PROCESS)

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Sec B, Line 15b, Process to establish compensation of other employees
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: SEE ABOVE (FORM 990, PART VI, LINE 15 AND AND SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 3: COMPENSATION REVIEW PROCESS)

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Sec C, Line 19, Required documents available to the public
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: HARVARD UNIVERSITY MAKES ITS ANNUAL FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AVAILABLE ON ITS WEBSITE. HARVARD'S CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY IS AVAILABLE ON HARVARD'S INTRANET, ACCESSIBLE TO MEMBERS OF THE HARVARD COMMUNITY. HARVARD'S PUBLIC CHARTER IS AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VII, SECTION A, LINE 1A, COLUMN (B), AVERAGE HOURS PER WEEK:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT TRACK HOURS WORKED BY TRUSTEES, OFFICERS, KEY EMPLOYEES, AND HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES. THE AVERAGE HOURS WORKED REPORTED ON PART VII, COLUMN (B) ARE ESTIMATES, WITH 60 HOURS PER WEEK AS AN APPROXIMATION FOR FULL-TIME EMPLOYMENT. THE HOURS PER WEEK DEVOTED TO RELATED ORGANIZATIONS REPRESENTS AN ESTIMATE OF TIME THE INDIVIDUAL SPENDS IN HIS/HER CAPACITY AS A MEMBER OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF HARVARD AFFILIATES.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART X, LINE 33, NET ASSETS:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: AS REPORTED IN THE UNIVERSITY'S FY14 FINANCIAL STATEMENTS, THE UNIVERSITY HAS CONSOLIDATED CERTAIN NON-CONTROLLING INTERESTS RELATING TO ITS INVESTMENTS IN REAL ASSETS UNDER ASU 2010-7. THESE NON-CONTROLLING INTERESTS REPRESENT THE PORTION OF THE REAL ASSETS NOT CONTROLLED BY THE UNIVERSITY, BUT REQUIRED TO BE PRESENTED ON THE UNIVERSITY'S BALANCE SHEET UNDER GENERALLY ACCEPTED ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES. THESE INTERESTS WERE $646.4 MILLION AS OF JUNE 30, 2014.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990 , Part XI, Line 9, Other changes in net assets or fund balances
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CHANGE IN NON-CONTROLLING INTERESTS IN POOLED INVESTMENT ACCOUNT - XXX-XX-XXXX; TRANSFERS TO NEW AFFILIATED ORGANIZATION - -XXX-XX-XXXX; TRANSFERS TO AFFILIATED ORGANIZATIONS - 50511862; OTHER CHANGES IN NET ASSETS - -10576044; CHANGE IN INTEREST IN TRUSTS HELD BY OTHERS - 24457609; CHANGE IN RETIREMENT OBLIGATIONS - 2762014; GAIN FROM DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS - 10500000;

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 7, Non-fixed payments
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE UNIVERSITY OFFERS INCENTIVE COMPENSATION FOR OUTSTANDING PERFORMANCE. BONUS AND INCENTIVE PAYMENTS FOR OFFICERS, KEY EMPLOYEES, AND HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES ARE LISTED IN PART II, COLUMN (B)(II).

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 8, Payments on contract that is subject to the initial contract exception
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: VICE PRESIDENTS THOMAS AND ROSOVSKY WERE COMPENSATED UNDER AN INITIAL CONTRACT DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2013. THIS COMPENSATION ARRANGEMENT WAS APPROVED IN ADVANCE BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OBTAINED AND RELIED UPON APPROPRIATE DATA AS TO COMPARABILITY PRIOR TO MAKING ITS DETERMINATION. ROSOVSKY'S COMPENSATION AFTER JULY 1, 2013 AND THOMAS' COMPENSATION AFTER JULY 1, 2014 WERE DETERMINED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE USING THE PROCESS DISCUSSED IN SCHEDULE O "COMPENSATION REVIEW PROCESS".

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: SCHEDULE J, PART II, SCHEDULE J SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: STEPHEN BLYTH IS A MANAGING DIRECTOR AND THE HEAD OF PUBLIC MARKETS FOR HARVARD MANAGEMENT COMPANY (HMC), A RELATED ORGANIZATION OF THE UNIVERSITY. DURING THE CALENDAR YEAR 2013, DR. BLYTH HELD A SENIOR FACULTY POSITION AT THE UNIVERSITY FOR WHICH HE RECEIVED A NOMINAL SALARY OF $1 PER MONTH. CONCURRENTLY, DR. BLYTH WAS A KEY EMPLOYEE OF HMC, WHICH HAS DISCLOSED HIS COMPENSATION FROM HMC, TOTALING $11,498,516, ON ITS FORM 990 FOR THE YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2014. NONE OF DR. BLYTH'S COMPENSATION FROM HMC RELATED TO HIS TEACHING POSITION AT THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY HAS NOT LISTED DR. BLYTH AS ONE OF ITS HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES GIVEN THE DISCLOSURE ON THE HMC FORM 990 AND IN ORDER TO HIGHLIGHT THE FIVE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES WHO RECEIVED COMPENSATION FROM THE UNIVERSITY. FORMER PROVOST HYMAN CONTINUES TO BE EMPLOYED BY THE UNIVERSITY. HE IS REPORTED AS 'FORMER' BECAUSE HE DID NOT SERVE IN AN OFFICER CAPACITY DURING FISCAL YEAR 2014. FELLOW BACOW HAD A PAID FACULTY APPOINTMENT DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2013 UNRELATED TO HIS WORK AS A MEMBER OF THE HARVARD CORPORATION. THE COMPENSATION FOR HIS ACADEMIC SERVICES IS REPORTED IN FORM 990, PART VII, SECTION A, COLUMN (D).
